SEARCH
Module org.klojang.jdbc
Package org.klojang.jdbc

Class SQLQuery

java.lang.Object
org.klojang.jdbc.SQLStatement<SQLQuery>
org.klojang.jdbc.SQLQuery
All Implemented Interfaces:
AutoCloseable
public final class SQLQuery extends SQLStatement<SQLQuery>

Facilitates the execution of SQL SELECT statements. SQLQuery instances are obtained via SQLSession.prepareQuery(). Here is an example of how to use the SQLQuery class: 


 SQL sql = SQL.simple("SELECT LAST_NAME FROM PERSON WHERE FIRST_NAME = :firstName");
 try(Connection con = ...) {
   try(SQLQuery query = sql.session(con).prepareQuery()) {
     query.bind("firstName", "John");
     // Collect all values in the first column of the ResultSet into a List
     List<String> lastNames = query.firstColumn();
   }
 }

Here is an example of a query that that contains both named parameters and template variables (see the comments for the SQL interface for the difference between the two): 


 SQL sql = SQL.template("""
  SELECT LAST_NAME
    FROM PERSON
   WHERE FIRST_NAME = :firstName
   ORDER BY ~%sortColumn%
  """);
 try(Connection con = ...) {
   return sql.session(con)
       .setIdentifier("sortColumn", "SALARY")
       .prepareQuery()
       .bind("firstName", "John")
       .firstColumn();
 }

  • Method Details

    • execute

      public ResultSet execute()
      Executes the query and returns the raw JDBC ResultSet. If the query had already been executed, it will not be executed again. Instead, the ResultSet generated by the first call to execute() will be returned. Call reset() to force the query to be re-executed.
      Returns:
      the ResultSet produced by the JDBC driver

    • lookup

      public <T> Result<T> lookup(Class<T> clazz)
      Executes the query and returns the value of the first column of the first row. The second time you call this method, you get the value of the first column of the second row, and so on. If there are no (more) rows in the ResultSet, Result.notAvailable() is returned. If the query had already been executed, it will not be executed again. Call reset() to force the query to be re-executed.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the value to be returned
      Parameters:
      clazz - the class of the value to be returned
      Returns:
      a Result containing the value of the first column of the first row or Result.notAvailable() if there are no (more) rows in the ResultSet

    • getInt

      public Result<Integer> getInt()
      Executes the query and returns the value of the first column of the first row as an Integer. Equivalent to lookup(Integer.class). The second time you call this method, you get the value of the first column of the second row, and so on. If there are no (more) rows in the ResultSet, Result.notAvailable() is returned. If the query had already been executed, it will not be executed again. Call reset() to force the query to be re-executed.
      Returns:
      a Result containing the value of the first column of the first row or Result.notAvailable() if there are no (more) rows in the ResultSet

    • getString

      public Result<String> getString()
      Executes the query and returns the value of the first column of the first row as a String. Equivalent to lookup(String.class). The second time you call this method, you get the value of the first column of the second row, and so on. If there are no (more) rows in the ResultSet, Result.notAvailable() is returned. If the query had already been executed, it will not be executed again. Call reset() to force the query to be re-executed.
      Returns:
      a Result containing the value of the first column of the first row or Result.notAvailable() if there are no (more) rows in the ResultSet

    • exists

      public boolean exists()
      Executes the query and returns true if the query yielded at least one row; false otherwise. If the query had already been executed, it will not be executed again. Call reset() to force the query to be re-executed. Note that this method will call ResultSet.next(), moving the cursor to the next row in the ResultSet. This will influence the outcome of the other methods of SQLQuery, and of subsequent calls to exists() for that matter. Only call this method if the only thing you are interested in is figuring out if a query yields a result, and nothing else.
      Returns:
      true if the query yielded at least one row; false otherwise

    • firstColumn

      public List<String> firstColumn()
      Executes the query and returns all values in the first column of the SELECT clause. Equivalent to firstColumn(String.class). If the query had already been executed, it will not be executed again. Call reset() to force the query to be re-executed.
      Returns:
      the values of the first column in the result set

    • firstColumn

      public <T> List<T> firstColumn(Class<T> clazz)
      Executes the query and returns all values in the first column of the SELECT clause. Equivalent to firstColumn(clazz, 10). If the query had already been executed, it will not be executed again. Call reset() to force the query to be re-executed.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the desired type of the values
      Parameters:
      clazz - the desired class of the values
      Returns:
      the values of the first column in the result set

    • firstColumn

      public <T> List<T> firstColumn(Class<T> clazz, int sizeEstimate)
      Executes the query and returns all values in the first column of the SELECT clause. In other words, this method will retrieve all rows satisfying the WHERE and LIMIT clauses (if any) and collect the values of the first column into a List. If the query had already been executed, it will not be executed again. Call reset() to force the query to be re-executed.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the desired type of the values
      Parameters:
      clazz - the desired class of the values
      sizeEstimate - the expected number of rows
      Returns:
      the values of the first column in the result set

    • getExtractor

      public MapExtractor getExtractor()
      Executes the query and returns a MapExtractor that you can use to convert the rows in the ResultSet into Map<String, Object> pseudo-objects. If the query had already been executed, it will not be executed again. Call reset() to force the query to be re-executed.
      Returns:
      a MapExtractor that you can use to convert the rows in the ResultSet into Map<String, Object> pseudo objects.

    • getExtractor

      public <T> BeanExtractor<T> getExtractor(Class<T> clazz)
      Executes the query and returns a BeanExtractor that you can use to convert the rows in the ResultSet into JavaBeans or records. If the query had already been executed, it will not be executed again. Call reset() to force the query to be re-executed.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the JavaBeans or records
      Parameters:
      clazz - the class of the JavaBeans or records
      Returns:
      a BeanExtractor that you can use to convert the rows in the ResultSet into JavaBeans or records.

    • getExtractor

      public <T> BeanExtractor<T> getExtractor(Class<T> clazz, Supplier<T> beanSupplier)
      Executes the query and returns a BeanExtractor that you can use to convert the rows in the ResultSet into JavaBeans. The provided class must not be a record type. If the query had already been executed, it will not be executed again. Call reset() to force the query to be re-executed.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the JavaBeans (must not be a record type)
      Parameters:
      clazz - the class of the JavaBeans
      beanSupplier - the supplier of the JavaBean instances. This would ordinarily be a method reference to the constructor of the JavaBean (like Person::new)
      Returns:
      a BeanExtractor that you can use to convert the rows in the ResultSet into JavaBeans.
